title: Bartering Restricted-Use Goods
vignette: In a designated project zone, Person A has project-specific supplies (e.g., special nutritional supplements for a health project) and says to Person B: "Here are some of my project supplements; give me some of your project's educational materials in exchange." Both items were acquired with restricted grant funds for their respective projects.

options.text: Barter is fine – an equal-value swap benefits both projects within the zone.
Forbidden; restricted-use items may only be used for their specific project or distributed as per grant rules, not bartered.

title: Community Asset Earmarked, Then Redirected
vignette: A coordinator manages livestock bought with a community development grant. She considers using the prize calf as collateral for her personal loan. The grant agreement bars private use of project assets. Is the pledge valid?

options.text: Valid – the asset has recognized monetary worth and can be used.
Invalid; assets designated for community or special purposes may not be used for private, unrelated transactions.

title: High-Value By-product from Restricted Purchase
vignette: Grant money restricted to Zone A buys steers for a nutrition program. The hides, now worth more than the beef, are left over. Must the hide revenue stay in Zone A, or can organisers spend it anywhere?

options.text: The byproduct is unrestricted; the project manager or organization can sell it and use the profit freely.
The byproduct retains the restricted status; its value must also be reinvested or used within the designated project area/purpose.

title: Accidental Purchase of Non-Approved Items with Restricted Funds
vignette: Someone accidentally uses restricted grant funds to purchase items not permitted by the grant terms (e.g., decorative items instead of essential supplies).

options.text: The purchase stands; use the items for the project in the designated area anyway, if possible. Make a note of the error.
The purchase is void; the funds must be restored to their restricted status (e.g., reimburse the grant), and the non-approved items should be disposed of or returned.

title: Switching Restricted Operating Cash to Capital Spend
vignette: Budget line "Consumables – Zone A" is used to buy a 3-year freezer instead of food. Finance asks whether the manager can keep the freezer or must move an equivalent sum back into the consumables account.

options.text: Transaction valid – treat the asset as an investment that will support future project activities/consumables.

Prohibited or requires special approval; must allocate an equivalent sum from appropriate budget lines to cover the intended consumables, or justify the change. The original funds were for immediate project needs.

title: Personal Use of Program Supplies in Harsh Field Conditions
vignette: Aid workers in a desert clinic have high-grade cooking oil meant for beneficiary rations. One staffer wants a bottle for skin protection against the sun. Supplies are tightly tracked. Is that private use allowed?

options.text: Yes; such ancillary personal use counts as valid utilization of the supplies under broad interpretation of "use."
No; the supplies must be strictly used for their primary intended purpose (e.g., ingestion for nutrition).

title: Compensating for Transport of Restricted Goods with Those Same Goods
vignette: A project manager asks a colleague to transport valuable, restricted-use project supplies (e.g., medical supplies for a clinic in a remote "designated zone") to the designated location. Can the manager offer a portion of these same supplies as compensation for the transport service?

options.text: Yes; it's fair in-kind compensation for labor and logistical costs.
No; giving a share as payment turns the restricted goods into a bartered commodity, violating their terms of use. Compensation should be from a separate, unrestricted source.

title: Unaccredited Vendor Inside the Spend-Zone
vignette: Restricted project coins must be spent inside Zone A. A pop-up stall sells the exact building materials the team needs but has no formal licence. May the team buy there or must they source only from listed vendors?

options.text: Permitted – treat the funds like cash for approved purchases within the zone; the vendor's status is secondary as long as the goods are used correctly.
Forbidden – using unaccredited vendors risks lack of quality control, improper documentation, or misuse of funds, undermining the project's integrity.

title: Taking Restricted-Use Items Outside Designated Zone After Entry
vignette: A grant requires certain project supplies (e.g., leftover high-nutrient food supplements) to be consumed or utilized only within a specific project zone ("designated zone"). After these supplies have been brought into the zone, can a project worker take them back to their home outside the zone if they intend to return with them later or use them for project purposes while temporarily away?

options.text: Allowed if the intent is to use them for the project or return them to the zone. Temporary removal is acceptable.
Disallowed; once officially brought into the designated zone, these specific items are 'locked in' and must be used or disposed of within that zone.

title: Transit Through the Spend-Zone
vignette: Shipment of lab reagents purchased with Zone A funds passes briefly through Zone A en route to Zone B, where they are scheduled for use. Does the stopover lock the reagents into Zone A usage?

options.text: Yes (Strict Interpretation) – mere entry into the designated zone triggers the use restriction for those specific items.

No (Flexible Interpretation) – if the primary intention and approval were for use in Zone B, mere transit through Zone A doesn't alter that. The restriction applies to final designated use, not incidental transit.

title: Insurance Payout on Spoiled Restricted Goods
vignette: A batch of Zone-A-only produce spoils en route and the insurer pays cash. Must that payout now be spent inside Zone A on replacement produce, or can managers source substitutes wherever is practical?

options.text: Replacement funds must be spent within the original designated zone (unless the damage was so severe and occurred far outside, making it impractical).
Replacement funds can be used more flexibly, especially if the compromise occurred outside the zone (unless it was minor and happened within the zone).

title: Does Packaging of Restricted Goods Also Become Restricted?
vignette: A supplier sells project-specific, restricted-use liquids in special, sealed containers. After the liquid is used according to project rules, do the empty containers themselves also gain a restricted status and need to be handled or disposed of according to project protocols?

options.text: Yes; the value and nature of the container are tied to the restricted contents. It should be managed accordingly.
No; only the contents were restricted. The empty container is general waste or can be repurposed freely.

title: Admin Surcharge on Converting Restricted Items
vignette: A supervisor redeems leftover restricted supplies bought by a junior staffer, converting them back to general funds. Normally a 20% admin fee applies when you redeem your own stock. Does the fee also apply here?

options.text: Yes; treat the subordinate's project expense like one's own for administrative purposes, including the surcharge.
No; the surcharge applies only when converting items from one's own direct budget allocation, not a subordinate's.

title: Exchanging Small Denomination Restricted Funds for Larger to Avoid Fees
vignette: A project has many small amounts of restricted funds from various small activities that are inconvenient to manage and would each incur a fee if converted separately. The project accountant exchanges all these small amounts for a single large-denomination voucher or sum of the same restricted type, partly to avoid multiple conversion fees.

options.text: Permitted; any consolidation that simplifies management and reduces administrative burden is valid.
Forbidden if the primary aim is to evade the standard conversion fees that would apply to multiple small sums.
